meanings.definition: A habitual gesture or way of speaking or behaving.
meanings.sent1: Her constant fidgeting with her hair was a mannerism that everyone noticed.
meanings.sent2: His polite mannerism made him well-liked by all his colleagues.
meanings.sent3: The way he always tapped his foot became a funny mannerism among his friends.
meanings.sent4: Her mannerism of always saying 'you know' was like a broken record.
meanings.sent5: The comedian imitated the politician's mannerism of pointing dramatically for laughs.

meanings.definition: An exaggerated or affected style in art or literature.
meanings.sent1: The artist's use of bright colors was a mannerism that divided critics.
meanings.sent2: The writer's flowery language was seen as a mannerism by some readers.
meanings.sent3: The over-the-top descriptions in the book were a humorous mannerism of the author.
meanings.sent4: Her painting style was a mannerism that set her apart from other artists.
meanings.sent5: The director's use of slow-motion became a signature mannerism in his films.

meanings.sent1: His love for collecting vintage toys was a mannerism that defined him.
meanings.sent2: The way she always wore mismatched socks was a cute mannerism.
meanings.sent3: His mannerism of humming while working added a unique touch to the office.
meanings.sent4: The dog's mannerism of tilting its head when confused was adorable.
meanings.sent5: The old house had a charming mannerism of creaking floorboards at night.
